content: Of Presidents who served, both George Washington and which other president were land surveyors before their political careers?

Both George Washington and Thomas Jefferson had experiences as land surveyors before they embarked on their political careers.

George Washington began his career as a surveyor at a young age. He received his first commission in 1748 when he was 16 years old, and he continued to work as a surveyor until the outbreak of the French and Indian War in 1754. His surveying experience not only helped him understand land and geography but also gave him a sense of responsibility and leadership, which later served him well as the first President of the United States.

Thomas Jefferson, on the other hand, although more known for his role as the primary author of the Declaration of Independence and as the third President, also had some experience in surveying. He was particularly interested in land measurement and ownership, which was crucial during the westward expansion of the United States. Jefferson's involvement in surveying was more intellectual and administrative, reflecting his broader interests in science, agriculture, and governance.

It's interesting to note that both presidents' backgrounds in surveying influenced their approaches to land policy and westward expansion during their presidencies. Their firsthand knowledge of land and its management played a significant role in shaping the early development of the United States.
